The list of training data partitions we consider can be seen in Table¬†1, where the values represent the overall percentage of training data across an entire layer of the network. For example, on a per-client level in the equal data partition setting, each device will in actuality hold 1/121121/12 of the entire training data (as there are 4 total devices) and each edge client will hold 1/6161/6 (there are 2 total edge clients). We also examine the scenario where the cloud holds the majority of the training data, which includes the case where it has access to a large public dataset. Lastly, we explore an extreme scenario, where almost all the training data is situated on the devices, reflecting tasks where a limited amount of public data samples are accessible.
The data is i.i.d. among all clients in the network.

We also analyze two training data partitions that are more extreme, referred to as the strong cloud bias and the strong devices bias cases (see Table¬†1). In these scenarios, we focus on analyzing the worst-case settings where the expected service rates are higher for the exits having less data points. In particular, we consider serving rates 80-15-5, 60-30-10, and 45-35-20 for the strong cloud bias partition (where the devices store less than 4% of the samples but need to serve a large fraction of requests), and serving rates 5-15-80, 10-30-60, and 20-35-45 for the strong devices bias partition. In the strong cloud bias setting, it can be useful to set p>0ùëù0p>0 for the most powerful clients such that they use their larger datasets to help training the simpler device models. This is an effective way to decrease œµgensubscriptitalic-œµgen\epsilon_{\text{gen}}, by increasing |S1,ùíë|subscriptùëÜ1ùíë|S_{1,\bm{p}}| and |S2,ùíë|subscriptùëÜ2ùíë|S_{2,\bm{p}}|, while not having an impact on œµbiassubscriptitalic-œµbias\epsilon_{\text{bias}}. However, there is still a trade-off, because assigning p>0ùëù0p>0 will increase œµoptsubscriptitalic-œµopt\epsilon_{\text{opt}} due to the later exits training for fewer epochs (as it uses some of its allotted training epochs to train the earlier exits). In Figure¬†3, we can see that the performance of the ‚ÄúServing Rate‚Äù strategy greatly improves as we increase pùëùp progressive from 0 to 0.1 to 0.2. The ‚ÄúEqual Weight‚Äù training strategy unsurprisingly struggles in this case because œµgensubscriptitalic-œµgen\epsilon_{\text{gen}} for Exit 1 is exceptionally high, due to it having such a small amount of training data, and its static weight assignment has no means of alleviating this issue.

references: We first evaluate three training strategies over seven different serving rate settings on ùö≤ùö≤\bm{\Lambda}, which cover the scenarios where devices serve from 5%percent55\% up to 80%percent8080\% of all the requests (Table¬†2). Overall, we can observe that as more requests are served on the cloud (left-most columns), the overall performance is increased since the cloud uses the most complex model for inference. In the 33-33-33 serving rate setting, the ‚ÄúEqual Weight‚Äù and ‚ÄúServing Rate‚Äù strategies share the same ùö≤~bold-~ùö≤\bm{\tilde{\Lambda}}, and thus have the same performance.

The results in Table¬†2 show that when the data is equally distributed or when bigger nodes have slightly more data, training the EEN by setting the empirical weight ùö≤~bold-~ùö≤\bm{\tilde{\Lambda}} equal to the serving rate ùö≤ùö≤\bm{\Lambda} is a good choice. This ‚ÄúServing Rate‚Äù strategy is especially useful when the CIS is expected to serve more requests from the devices, which is an important scenario when the network budget is limited or communication cost needs to be reduced.
Besides, we note that it is often not necessary to require larger nodes to help train the small models as proposed in¬†[5]. In these two partition settings, all the exits had a sufficiently large dataset portion that œµgensubscriptitalic-œµgen\epsilon_{\text{gen}} was not unreasonably large for any exit.

Under the strong devices bias data partition, the system would benefit from weaker clients periodically training the larger exits. Other works such as HeteroFL¬†[3] have considered this scenario assuming that resources limit the size of the model to be used at inference, but not at training. Under this assumption, it would be possible to tune pùëùp to obtain exactly the same results as in Figure¬†3, and in particular the ‚ÄúServing Rate‚Äù strategy would still outperform the ‚ÄúEqual Weight‚Äù one. If instead we consider that resource constraints apply both at inference and training, Theorem¬†1 suggests an alternative approach. The bound indicates that having Exit 3 train on a small dataset may significantly increase œµgensubscriptitalic-œµgen\epsilon_{\text{gen}}. We can compensate for this effect by selecting Œõ~3<Œõ3subscript~Œõ3subscriptŒõ3\tilde{\Lambda}_{3}<\Lambda_{3} (and conversely Œõ~1>Œõ1subscript~Œõ1subscriptŒõ1\tilde{\Lambda}_{1}>\Lambda_{1}) at the expense of introducing a bias œµbias>0subscriptitalic-œµbias0\epsilon_{\text{bias}}>0.
In Table¬†3, we present the results of a simple heuristic which modifies the aggregation weights in this direction:
